title: 111_s1819
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Civil Rights Center and Museum Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges the significance of the Greensboro sit-in of 1960, which sparked nonviolent protests against segregation across the United States. Over 70,000 people participated in similar demonstrations by 1961 in over 60 cities. This led to the establishment of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The sit-in movement in the United States against private-sector segregation led to over 70,000 people participating in demonstrations in 60 cities by August 1961. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum, located at the site where the movement began, serves as an archival and teaching facility exploring the global struggle for civil and human rights. The International Civil Rights Center and Museum, located at the site where the sit-in movement began, will open on February 1, 2010, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the movement. It will serve as an archival center and teaching facility exploring the international struggle for civil and human rights. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $1 silver coins in commemoration of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Design of coins for the $1 silver coins commemorating the International Civil Rights Center and Museum includes specifications such as weight, diameter, and composition. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, with inscriptions including the coin's value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The coins minted under this Act will have a design emblematic of the International Civil Rights Center and Museum, with inscriptions of the coin's value, year, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, minted at a single facility (preferably the United States Mint at West Point, New York), and only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2010. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in section 7, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before the coins are issued. The Secretary will make bulk sales of coins at a discount and accept prepaid orders before issuance. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. Surcharges go to the International Civil Rights Center and Museum for program development. The Comptroller General can audit the Museum's expenditures.
